title: 104_s2005
content: The text chunk "SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE; FINDINGS." is a concise summary of the section's title and its purpose. The "Patient Communications Protection Act of 1996" ensures patients have access to relevant information for healthcare decisions, upholding principles of informed consent and ethical standards for physicians. It aims to regulate health plans operating across states for uniform treatment of providers and patients. The "Patient Communications Protection Act of 1996" regulates health plans operating in one State and across several States. SEC. 2. PROHIBITION OF INTERFERENCE WITH CERTAIN MEDICAL COMMUNICATIONS. An entity offering a health plan cannot restrict medical communication in contracts with healthcare providers, but can set mutually agreed upon terms. The curr_chunk discusses policies and procedures related to ensuring the quality of healthcare, nullifying certain provisions, defining medical communication, and imposing civil money penalties for violations. The curr_chunk outlines the procedures for imposing civil money penalties on healthcare providers for violations, with definitions provided for "health care provider" and "health plan." These penalties are subject to the same provisions as penalties under the Social Security Act. The curr_chunk defines "health plan" as any public or private plan providing health benefits, including organizations of healthcare providers. It also states that third party administrators of employee welfare benefit plans are considered entities offering health plans. State laws can be enforced as long as they are more protective of medical communications than federal requirements. The effective date for this section is 180 days after the enactment of the Act.
